issue.title: Finalize XML Format for Test Results
issue.body:
Get comments from the community.

Specific issues:
- Document the schema
- How to record result state: two attributes or one?

body:
Proposal:
1. Move the entire environment element to the assembly-level test-suite. It will be produced by the framework in the case of NUnit 3.0, by the driver for NUnit 2.x and any other extension drivers.
2. Rename attribute nunit-version to framework-version, since that's what it is
3. Add two attributes to the test run element. (This could be an abbreviated environment element but attributes seem better for just two items)
   - nunit-version (console-version? engine-version?)
   - clr-version

This will result in some duplication when there are multiple assemblies but will serve us better when we run tests on different machines.
Sounds good. I think nunit-version should show the engine version, not the version of the runner.
What should it show for non-engine builds (nunitlite)?

You would get the same assembly-level environment element as for the
console. That's the main reason I like this move. You wouldn't get a
test-run element at all IIRC.

On Tue, Oct 27, 2015 at 12:15 PM, Neil Colvin notifications@github.com
wrote:

> What should it show for non-engine builds (nunitlite)?
> 
> 窶能n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/887#issuecomment-151614871.

One thing I don't like is `framework-version` as it could mean any framework. It is probably clear because clr-version comes next, but it is obviously a version, so it could be `nunit-framework`. The engine could insert `nunit-engine` or nunitlite could insert `nunitlite`.

Should you also add `nunit-engine` to the environment element that you are moving down to the assemblies? Once we go multiple machine, the engine version on that machine could be different.

Once we go multiple machines, the information about both machines needs to be in the results.

They likely will not be the same.

Information for each machine should be in the environment node that is
being moved to the assembly level.
On Oct 27, 2015 4:16 PM, "Neil Colvin" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Once we go multiple machines, the information about both machines needs to
> be in the results.
> 
> They likely will not be the same.
> 
> 窶能n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/887#issuecomment-151630009.

Rob: I used framework thinking it might **not** be an NUnit framework in
the future. In the case of a foreign framework, the driver would have to
provide this.

Neil: If we run on multiple machines then each machine would have a
different assembly-level suite element with it's own environment.

On Tue, Oct 27, 2015 at 1:22 PM, Rob Prouse notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Information for each machine should be in the environment node that is
> being moved to the assembly level.
> On Oct 27, 2015 4:16 PM, "Neil Colvin" notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> > Once we go multiple machines, the information about both machines needs
> > to
> > be in the results.
> > 
> > They likely will not be the same.
> > 
> > 窶能n> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> > https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/887#issuecomment-151630009.
> 
> 窶能n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/887#issuecomment-151632778.

rename.from: Move environmental information to the appropriate level in the result file.
rename.to: Move environment and settings elements to the assembly suite in the result file.

body:
I changed the title to reflect that this deals with both the environment element and the settings element. Although some settings are provided by the command-line and are therefore the same for every assembly, many settings have default values, which are only known within the framework.

By moving at least some settings to the assembly level, the engine does not have to know how the particular framework calculates its default.
